entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French muntaine, from Vulgar Latin *montanea, from feminine of *montaneus of a mountain, alteration of Latin montanus, from mont-, mons

def.dt: :a landmass that projects conspicuously above its surroundings and is higher than a hill
:any of various trees or shrubs (genus Sorbus) of the rose family with pinnate leaves and red or orange-red fruits
:an all-terrain bicycle with wide knobby tires, straight handlebars, and typically 18 to 21 gears
:a bluebird (Sialia currucoides) of western North America having a blue-breasted rather than red-breasted male
:a low evergreen shrub (Vaccinium vitis-idaea) of the heath family that is native to north temperate uplands and has red edible berries called also lingonberry
:a ruminant mammal (Oreamnos americanus) of mountainous northwestern North America that has a thick yellowish-white coat and slightly curved horns and resembles a goat
:a gorilla (Gorilla gorilla beringei) inhabiting the Virunga mountain range
:a North American evergreen shrub or small tree (Kalmia latifolia) of the heath family with glossy leaves and umbels of rose-colored or white flowers
